natural problem: Eight women of different heights are at a party. Each woman decides to only shake hands with women shorter than herself. How many handshakes take place?
natural solution: Because the women are of different heights, any handshake will take place between two people, one of whom is taller than the other. Of course, the shorter of the two will not participate in the handshake because her handshake partner is not shorter than herself.
Applying this logic to all of the pairs, there are $\boxed{0}$ handshakes.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes women :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. i \<noteq> j \<and> i \<in> {1..8} \<and> j \<in> {1..8} \<longrightarrow> women i \<noteq> women j"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i \<in> {1..8} \<Longrightarrow> (\<forall>j. j \<in> {1..8} \<and> women j < women i \<longrightarrow> (i, j) \<in> handshakes)"
and h2 : "handshakes = {(i, j) | i j. i \<in> {1..8} \<and> j \<in> {1..8} \<and> women j < women i}"
shows  "card handshakes = 0"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Eight women of different heights are at a party. Each woman decides to only shake hands with women shorter than herself. How many handshakes take place? The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 Because the women are of different heights, any handshake will take place between two people, one of whom is taller than the other. Of course, the shorter of the two will not participate in the handshake because her handshake partner is not shorter than herself.
 Applying this logic to all of the pairs, there are $\boxed{0}$ handshakes.
 *)

theorem
fixes women :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. i \<noteq> j \<and> i \<in> {1..8} \<and> j \<in> {1..8} \<longrightarrow> women i \<noteq> women j"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i \<in> {1..8} \<Longrightarrow> (\<forall>j. j \<in> {1..8} \<and> women j < women i \<longrightarrow> (i, j) \<in> handshakes)"
and h2 : "handshakes = {(i, j) | i j. i \<in> {1..8} \<and> j \<in> {1..8} \<and> women j < women i}"
shows  "card handshakes = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In a gathering of 8 women, each woman only shakes hands with the women who have a smaller number than her. If each woman has a unique number, how many handshakes are there in total? The final answer is 0.

In a group of 8 women, each woman shakes hands with every other woman exactly once. How many handshakes are there in total?

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes women :: "nat set" and handshake :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "card women = 8"
and h1 : "\<forall>w1 w2. w1 \<in> women \<and> w2 \<in> women \<and> w1 \<noteq> w2 \<longrightarrow> (handshake w1 w2 \<longleftrightarrow> w1 > w2)"
shows  "card {(w1, w2). w1 \<in> women \<and> w2 \<in> women \<and> handshake w1 w2} = 0"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Eight women of different heights are at a party. Each woman decides to only shake hands with women shorter than herself. How many handshakes take place? The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 Because the women are of different heights, any handshake will take place between two people, one of whom is taller than the other. Of course, the shorter of the two will not participate in the handshake because her handshake partner is not shorter than herself.
 Applying this logic to all of the pairs, there are $\boxed{0}$ handshakes.
 *)

theorem
fixes women :: "nat set" and handshake :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "card women = 8"
and h1 : "\<forall>w1 w2. w1 \<in> women \<and> w2 \<in> women \<and> w1 \<noteq> w2 \<longrightarrow> (handshake w1 w2 \<longleftrightarrow> w1 > w2)"
shows  "card {(w1, w2). w1 \<in> women \<and> w2 \<in> women \<and> handshake w1 w2} = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes handshakes :: nat and women :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "inj_on women {1..8}"
and h1 : "distinct (map women [1..8])"
and h2 : "\<forall>i j. i \<in> {1..8} \<and> j \<in> {1..8} \<and> i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> (handshakes = 1 \<longleftrightarrow> women i > women j)"
shows  "handshakes = 0"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Eight women of different heights are at a party. Each woman decides to only shake hands with women shorter than herself. How many handshakes take place? The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 Because the women are of different heights, any handshake will take place between two people, one of whom is taller than the other. Of course, the shorter of the two will not participate in the handshake because her handshake partner is not shorter than herself.
 Applying this logic to all of the pairs, there are $\boxed{0}$ handshakes.
 *)

theorem
fixes handshakes :: nat and women :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "inj_on women {1..8}"
and h1 : "distinct (map women [1..8])"
and h2 : "\<forall>i j. i \<in> {1..8} \<and> j \<in> {1..8} \<and> i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> (handshakes = 1 \<longleftrightarrow> women i > women j)"
shows  "handshakes = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a group of 8 women, each woman shakes hands with every other woman exactly once. However, a handshake only counts if the woman with the higher number shakes hands with a woman with a lower number. How many handshakes took place if none of the handshakes counted? The final answer is 0.
